importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the plane crash, which occurred on September 18, 2025, marks a tragic event involving a prominent music songwriter, prompting public attention to aviation safety and communication protocols in commercial and private flights.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The incident occurred during a specific flight operation on September 18, 2025, highlighting a critical moment in aviation safety where miscommunication and procedural deviation led to a fatal crash.

keyTakeAways: Brett James, a Grammy-winning songwriter, died in a plane crash on September 18, 2025, in Franklin, North Carolina, along with two others.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) determined the plane entered a 'tightening spiral' during flight, though no mechanical failure was found.
James had requested a visual approach to runway 7, which was approved by air traffic control, but failed to tune to the common traffic advisory frequency (CTAF) as instructed.
James announced his position at 6,800 feet and intended a 360-degree turn, but did not change the radio frequency, leading to loss of communication with air traffic control.
The aircraft, a Cirrus SR22T, flew over the runway, executed a left turn, and then descended into a spiral before crashing.

James was a highly influential songwriter who collaborated with major artists such as Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, Keith Urban, and Kenny Chesney, including co-writing 'Out Last Night' and 'Jesus, Take the Wheel' for Carrie Underwood.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Grammy-winning songwriter Brett James, known for his collaborations with major artists like Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, and Keith Urban, died in a plane crash on September 18, 2025, in Franklin, North Carolina. The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) reported that the plane, a Cirrus SR22T, entered a 'tightening spiral' during a visual approach to runway 7 after James failed to tune to the common traffic advisory frequency (CTAF), despite air traffic control's instructions. James had announced his position and intended a 360-degree turn, but communication was lost, and the aircraft descended into a spiral before crashing. No mechanical issues were found in the plane. The incident underscores the importance of radio protocol adherence in private aviation and marks a significant loss for the music industry.
title: Songwriter Brett James’ plane enters 'tightening spiral' before crashing, NTSB says
